_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Minnesota Dept of Ag Rules & Regulations
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Utilize MDA forms for maintenance inspections on equipment
_prev_prog_2.Description: This facility complies with the various rules and regulations governing the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Inspection, maintenance and employee training are important components of our accident prevention program

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Farm Service 

233 West Ciro Street

PO Box 68

Truman, MN 56088

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



The Coop board, management and employees at Central Farm Service, Mapleton, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information and Regulated Substance:



The primary activity involved at the facility is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, handled and distributed for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients.



The facility has 2-30,000 gallon storage tanks with a maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored of approximately 280,000 pounds; and approximately 340,000 pounds available capacity in 1,000 and 1,450 gallon nurse tanks.  The maximum quantity handled at one time would be the unloading of a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The facility has implemented Minnesota Dept. of Agriculture rules, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility is required to conduct a semi-annual inspection of all bulk and nurse tank equipment, including load and unload equipment, and perform any needed maintenance to the equipment found during the inspections. Visual checks are to be conducted daily at the facility.



4. The Five-year Accident History:  



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have: 



a) Caus

ed any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or 

b) To our knowledge resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



5.  The Emergency Response Program:



The facility and/or facility personnel:

a) Has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and

40 CFR 68.95. The plan includes a response plan regarding anhydrous ammonia releases and what

to do in the event of a release. Emergency action plan and response training is discussed at

employee annual training sessions, including training every July relative to overall emergency

planning and response.

b) Undergoes anhydrous ammonia training, including emergency response training every fall.

c) Has an Incident Response Plan as required per Minnesota Statutes and Rules.

d) Has provided state and local authorities the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

e) Has coordinated and works with local emergency responders;

f) Has a Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan for quick access and reference.

g) Has a Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community and environment in which we operate.



6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Safety improvements are an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  Central Farm Service plans to continue education and training for employees along with periodic inspections by the local fire department.
